executive_summary: The market for industry services is expanding. New businesses are entering the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The market has been gaining new customers and revenue due to increased preferences for low-cost services and interest in new service offerings. Demographic trends have eroded the traditional popularity of burial, especially over the past decade.
Aquamation and green burial services are recent innovations in cremation, setting it apart in new ways from traditional burial.

As the popularity of cremation has grown, more companies have entered the industry. Notably, most companies are expected to be existing funeral home establishments. Although large public companies are active, service delivery remains localized and fragmented.
Bio Cremation (Aquamation) is a relatively new, costly process and more environmentally friendly than flame-based cremation, with fewer air emissions.

This older demographic is estimated to represent the industry's second-largest market because of its high death rate.
Individuals aged 45 to 84 are more likely to be cremated.

products_and_services.product_description: Most human cremations occur in facilities affiliated with a funeral home. These establishments have a competitive advantage over standalone crematoria because they provide the full scope of death care services and products (embalming, preparing a body for open-casket memorial services before cremation, urns, and caskets).

The resale of purchased merchandise is estimated to account for over a quarter of revenue. Urns, the containers where loved ones typically receive cremains, account for the bulk of this category. According to the latest data from the National Funeral Directors Association, the median price of an urn was $295.00 in 2021. However, bejeweled or other specialty urns can reach far higher price ranges. Although urns will continue to account for most of the segment revenue, alternative products are sold (synthetic diamonds made from human ashes, cremains encapsulated in jewelry, vinyl records, and tattoo ink made with a mixture of cremated remains).

As Americans' emotional attachment to their pets has grown, they have sought the same memorialization and closure upon their deaths as the passing of human relatives. Although pet cremation is a fast-growing service segment for the industry, it has remained relatively steady because human cremation has also grown more popular.

Cremations at standalone facilities, those unaffiliated with a funeral home, account for only a small share of industry establishments, as consumers typically favor funeral homes for their broad scope of product and service offerings. This segment appeals to customers prioritizing lower costs, as it often comes without many of the added services provided by a funeral home.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for cremation services is determined more specifically by consumers' affinity for cremation instead of burial. Cremation is relatively new in Western history; many religions have traditionally favored or even mandated the interment of human remains. In 1960, fewer than 5.0% of Americans were cremated upon death, while funerals today are split almost evenly between burial and cremation. Over time, a softening stance on cremation by some religions, notably the Catholic Church, has contributed to a more favorable view of cremation among Americans; however, many religions still oppose the practice. Meanwhile, the declining religiosity of the US population has made these concerns less relevant; according to Pew Research, 26.0% of US adults did not identify with a religion in 2019, up from 23.0% in 2009 (latest data available). Fewer funerals have conformed to religious traditions, enabling more consumers to opt for cremation.

The cost has also been a driver of demand for cremation services. According to the National Funeral Directors Association, the median price of a burial (embalming, body preparation services, memorial service) is an estimated $7,848, while the median cost of a cremation is $6,970. The lower cost of cremation has made it an attractive option for many consumers.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Cremation servicers largely support the domestic market. Some international crematory repatriations (returning a person to their country of birth) occur for defense personnel and US citizens who die overseas.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is the most populous region in the United States, with the largest share of crematoria and Florida leads the region in crematoria. Florida has the largest share of the elderly population (age 65 and older) in the US. Even as Florida leads the region in crematoria, the remainder of the region has among the lowest cremation rates in the country, likely owing to the prevalence of traditional religious preferences for burial.

The Great Lakes region has a disproportionately high share of crematoria establishments compared to its population share. These densely populated urban areas account for a higher percentage of industry establishments. The interpretation is that large cities tend to have more transient populations, and consumers without firmly established local roots have increasingly favored cremation over burial.

The Mid-Atlantic region has a disproportionately high share of crematoria establishments compared to its population share. These densely populated urban areas account for a higher percentage of industry establishments. The interpretation is that large cities tend to have more transient populations, and consumers without firmly established local roots have increasingly favored cremation over burial.
The Southwest's share of locations fall short of the population in part attributable to Texas having a small percentage of elderly compared to other states in the US.
The West's share of locations fall short of the population in part attributable to California having a small percentage of elderly compared to other states in the US.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Most states require licensure of both crematoria and funeral homes, though state regulations vary on individual staff licensing. Embalmers, cremation technicians and funeral directors in many states undergo mandatory training and examination to be authorized for work in the industry. Most states also regularly inspect industry establishments; some have additional regulations about emissions from crematory furnaces.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE FUNERAL RULE, FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION (FTC)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Funeral Rule requires companies that sell both funeral goods and services to itemize price upfront and prevent requiring the purchase of a casket or urn as a condition for providing cremation while accommodating customers that purchase such merchandise from a third party. Penalties are imposed for noncompliance.

regulations_points.regulation_title: COVID-19 GUIDELINES, CENTER FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC)
regulations_points.regulation_description: As essential service providers, establishments were permitted to remain open through COVID-19, but were subjected to strict guidelines on working on the deceased who had COVID-19.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Funeral homes familiar with regulations face reduced legal barriers to entry. Barriers to entry are low in the pet cremation segment as regulatory oversight is less restrictive than for human remains.
The upfront capital costs of establishing a crematorium are high and it can take substantial time for new businesses to build a customer base to support these expenses.
Due to the sensitivity of death care, consumers are likely to favor operators with a positive reputation, which can be a formidable and time-consuming task.
Capital costs raise a minor barrier as entry requires fixed investments for building and processing equipment.

basis_points.basis_description: Reputation is a competitive factor due to the sensitivity required for death care services. Price competition plays a significant role. The breadth of offerings is essential for attracting consumers who opt for cremation but still seek assistance with planning a funeral service or preparing the body for an open casket.

The popularity of cremation has risen in recent years and more funeral homes have begun to offer both services, reducing external competition for the industry. However, for some funeral homes providing both burial and cremation, increasing demand for cremation has posed a challenge by diverting customers toward a lower-cost funeral option.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Cremation services have had a low level of market share concentration characterized by small businesses that cater to local needs.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Changing Consumer Preferences Will Spur Entry and Concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: Increasing demand for lower-cost options and the entry of large public companies into the funeral space set the stage for the traditional funeral companies' acquisition of cremation service companies, spurring concentration.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Costly Technology and Cremation Service Substitutes May Inspire Consolidation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Entry requires upfront costs. Established funeral homes and large crematories may choose to purchase existing companies outright, spurring consolidation and concentration. Cremation substitutes may increase in popularity, hurting smaller standalone companies that do not provide various services, making them an acquisition target.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Cremation services infrastructure incurs high upfront and depreciation cost
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Cremation equipment, including furnaces and peripheral equipment, is costly. A furnace scrubber, which cleans residue inside a furnace, can cost upward of $400,000.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital intensity is low to moderate in crematory services. Human crematories require a cremation chamber or system to be installed in a fixed location. Other investments such as buildings, a cooler for housing remains prior to cremation and remains processing equipment are necessary for operations. Cremation equipment is usually purchased rather than leased due to custom installation requirements. Automated cremation chambers have reduced labor requirements for monitoring machines but labor is still necessary for tasks (moving bodies, cleaning, maintenance).

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changing Consumer Preferences and COVID-19 Stimulate Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Cremation has steadily risen as a portion of funeral services surpassing burials. New services offered by cremation providers are maintaining the increased demand and bolstering preferences for cremation over traditional burial. The need for cremation services and subsequent revenue spiked due to increased death rates of COVID-19.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consolidation Trends Foster Volatility for Some Companies
volatility_points.volatility_description: Larger corporations acquiring minor, independent providers reap economies of scale and competitive advantage leading to stiffer price competition and volatility in the market. For companies providing traditional burial and cremation services, volatility will be less severe as they provide a larger selection of services.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: One new technology challenging cremation is Aquamation (water cremation), which provides a lower environmental impact but is more expensive than cremation. Another technology that is a challenge to cremation is cryonics, the process of freezing a person immediately after death in the hopes of stemming the decomposition of their brain and preserving the potential for reanimation of the corpse if the problem of human mortality is somehow, someday solved. However, this technology is enormously expensive.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Cost and safety concerns have advanced the integration of technology into processes
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Traditionally, materials such as coal and wood were used to fuel crematories. Since heating could not be controlled effectively, cremation was potentially dangerous and the time necessary to completely dispose of a body was irregular. New cremation systems employ natural or propane gases that are regulated by computers to optimize temperature. Complex algorithms manage heating cycles based on the size and composition of the body, ensuring the timely incineration of the body and eliminating mixing human remains with those from spent fuels. Knowing when a cremation will occur enables providers to schedule services and maximize available resources. Advanced technology also allows cremation systems to process gases, removing odors and potentially dangerous pollutants. Many new systems integrate a secondary burning chamber that removes any remaining organic material from exhaust gases.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales reliant on the overall health of the US economy (i.e. consumer spending and per capita disposable income)?
FAQs.answer: Consumers require industry services during all stages of the business cycle, but favorable economic conditions tend to increase per-client revenue and profit.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer a referral rewards program to attract new customers?
FAQs.answer: The nature of the funeral business does not lend itself to special promotions or customer rewards, but industry businesses often gain new business from word-of-mouth referrals.

FAQs.question: How does your company respond to fluctuations in demand?
FAQs.answer: Industry entrants tend to be existing funeral home operators that offer cremation services in response to growing demand.

FAQs.question: How does your company provide ancillary services to diversify revenue streams?
FAQs.answer: Funeral homes' success is determined by their ability to sell added products alongside basic cremation services.

FAQs.question: Is your company leveraging new technology, such as mobile phone applications, to streamline booking and communication with clients?
FAQs.answer: Although funeral homes often emphasize a human touch in their services, online client management applications can also help enhance services.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
FAQs.answer: Funeral homes are increasingly investing in crematoriums to keep up with a growing preference for this method of funereal disposition.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Funeral homes work with toxic chemicals and perform a sensitive service, and are therefore highly regulated.

FAQs.question: Have you recently experienced any regulatory expenses that have significantly impacted profitability?
FAQs.answer: Many key funereal occupations have strict licensing requirements, which vary by state.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: There is no significant seasonality in the death rate, so the industry does not have to compensate for seasonal cash flows.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare with those of your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Funeral home chains often generate higher profit due to their purchasing power and ability to spread central administrative costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company build a good reputation? What strategies does your company employ to attract new customers?
FAQs.answer: Operators should strive to maintain a good reputation to ensure new customers.

FAQs.question: Which government regulations affect your company? What does your company do to comply with government regulations?
FAQs.answer: Complying with all government regulations is a necessity for operators in the industry.

FAQs.question: Which type of locations work best for your company? How do you sell product in locations that are not high profile?
FAQs.answer: Having a high profile or visible location with significant passing traffic is important.

FAQs.question: Do you find that revenue trends in line with the level of household disposable income? How can your company adapt to this threat?
FAQs.answer: As disposable income levels rise, families may be more inclined to pay for more expensive traditional funeral services, decreasing demand for the industry

FAQs.question: How does your company market services to people in this age group? What percentage of your cremation services come from this age group?
FAQs.answer: The proportion of the population aged 65 and older is a positive indicator of demand for cremation services

FAQs.question: What factors affect the number of cremations for your company? How does your company take advantage of this opportunity?
FAQs.answer: The number of cremations compared with traditional burials is the strongest driver of industry growth. Demand for cremation has increased over the past five years.
